msIdentifier.collection: The Arnold and Deanne Kaplan Collection of Early American Judaica

body.p:
Now, do not throw this down
and say what have I to do with the business
of another ? or look at the signature and
say what a liberty, for her to write me a
private letter, for this is strictly private as far
as I am concerned, remember not even my
Husband having the slightest Idea of such a presumption
in me; but my heart is full, and I must
tell some one that will and can do something
you have in your periodical often recommended
the Israelite to give their sons trades, that would
raise the dignity of our Nation, and develope the
genius of our youth, such as sculpture &c &c
now here in our midst is a son of Israel (I have
just returned from his little shop) who is a most
complete artist in designing and sculpture
his work is all that can be wished, as Mr.
Theodore Lexas, Mr J Soria? and many others

can tell you he has just finished the stone
for Mr Sampson Simpson, which will
be erected on Sunday 3d of tebet, it being
my Dear Fathers zotesight? we intend setting
one for Dear Charity at the same time, this
it was that called me to this little Shop
now, this man is told by our big men
he must not only work better but cheaper
than others or he will not be encouraged
by his own, is not this grievous to hear in
a poor man, wife, and six children to support
by his own labor, and he must work cheaper
than a rich one, that can employ 300 men, because he is so unfortunate as to be of the seed
of Israel—

A professor of the Medical College in
Crosby St. for whom he had done some fine
carving to match a piece, was so pleased with his
work he commenced a conversation with him
asking him many things, that led him to say
he was a Jew, when the proffessor expressed great
surprise, and said I thought your people prefered

p.rend: The following is written in pencil at the bottom of the page.

body.p:
traffic, to labor, the art of sculpture I thought
required too much labor for a Jew to choose for a
living—now those that have employed him
amongst us have paid him and remembered him
no more, no one of influence knows him, and
he will be again obliged to return to journey work
as he has been foreman in one shop in Manchester
4 years, having credentials therefrom, and here in
Brooklyn in Peter O Haras establishment 12 mo
where he drew the design and done the fine work
of a Monument that was sent to Virginia for
5.000$ with 'done by Peter O Hara Brooklyn' on it
and another standing in Newark for 600, and many
others, as he was foreman of 300 men, now I feel I
have been wronged, if a Jew does wrong is it not a
disgrace to all Jews? if a Jew is honorable in good and
great works, does he not add to the dignity of all
Israel. now all this man requires is to have his work
brought out and made known. Oh! if our Dear Brother
Solomon were here, he felt with me, in those things
to encourage the talent of Israel was the pride of his
heart. God rest. and Amen

p.rend: The following is written in pencil at the bottom of the page.

body.p:
this man now lives with his family in poverty, or at
least privation, must take his son from school
to peddle Brushes (a fine intelligent lad) and
why? because he must work for what he terms Bosies?
his fine sculpture must decorate Greenwood, he
recieving 15$ for what the Bos gets 50, if he
only could be made known, and his own people
would pay him the same as another stranger,
his Hebrew lettering is truly beautiful as you
will see, if ever you visit this city, I know you will
seek him out, I know you are tired of reading
this but if I should write 20 pages I could not say
all I feel therefore will conclude only asking
you to say shall we give our Boys trades
or make traders of our Boys
do not mention this to Brother David
Last line written upside-down at the bottom of the page.
